Anomalies, cobordisms, and the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem

Feb 4, 2020

Last time, I mentioned a project that I’ve been working on with a grad student in the physics department. We’re trying to understand anomaly cancellations, and there’s a slick argument of Witten’s (I think? I learnt it from this paper) which explains this via the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem. Let’s recall the setup. We’ll work in Euclidean signature.

Let be an odd-dimensional manifold (one-dimensional time direction), and consider a massless Dirac fermion on , with action

where is the Dirac operator. (OK, we should assume that the manifold is spin, etc. But we’re contemplating physics, so I’m gonna allow assumptions to remain implicit.) Then, the path integral of the -field is the determinant of the imaginary Dirac operator . Because is Hermitian (boils down to the Hermitian-ness of the gamma matrices), its eigenvalues are real, and so . From a physical perspective, this stems from time-reversal invariance (for which the masslessness of our fermion is important): time-reversal has the effect of conjugating the partition function.

Now, the product is real, but its sign is not well-defined. To see this, couple to a background gauge field and metric such that is real for this configuration. Consider a gauge transformation which sends to , and consider the straight line in the configuration space of the field theory connecting to . Then the gauge-invariance of the Dirac operator implies that the spectrum of the Dirac operator for both of these background field configurations is the same — but the “spectral flow” of the Dirac operator implies that the “number of positive/negative eigenvalues” (that phrase doesn’t make mathematical sense, because there are infinitely many eigenvalues) could change. In particular, the sign of changes everytime an eigenvalue of the Dirac operator passes through zero under this straight-line path in the configuration space. This is called the parity anomaly: the sign of isn’t well-defined.

That doesn’t mean that the theory is inconsistent, just that we can’t quantize it without violating time-reversal invariance. Let’s introduce a Pauli-Villars regulator (so we’re cutting off the mass at some ); then, the regulated determinant of is

If is large, then each contributes the phase or to , depending on the sign of . So

Again, we need to write down this infinite sum properly. This is the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer -invariant : it could be taken to be

There’s actually an expression for the -invariant (due to Melrose?) as a Mellin transform

In any case, if we take this to be the regulated definition of the partition function, then the sign ambiguity is resolved, and the resulting expression for is gauge invariant. The only issue we have left is that is not time-reversal invariant. This manifests as the fact that need not be real. Note that we can also equally well choose a regularization such that (rather than ).

It’s clear that we’re trying real hard to get the index of the Dirac operator to show up, but all we’ve got is thee -invariant. This is fixed by the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem. Suppose that our -dimensional manifold is the boundary of a -manifold (the “bulk”), and that our fermion field is a boundary mode of some fermion field on (and assume that the spin structure, gauge fields, etc. also extend to ). Then adding on “gravitational terms” (the A-hat genus) to the bulk leads to the combined bulk-boundary system being time-reversal invariant (i.e., the partition function of the bulk-boundary system is real). Namely, if denotes the Atiyah-Singer characteristic class (living in cohomological dimension ; this can be expressed in terms of the A-hat genus of ; Chern-Weil theory gives an expression for this in terms of curvature, and so it’s a “gravitational term”), then introduce the action

on the “bulk” . The combined bulk-boundary system has partition function

The Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem states that

So the combined bulk-boundary system has partition function . Because the index of the Dirac operator is an integer, the path integral is real; it is also invariant under time-reversal and gauge transformations.

Although we’ve resolved these issues, we’ve introduced a new one in the process of fixing them: if it does not depend on the choice of , then would be a good definition of the path integral for the fermion field on . To emphasize this possible dependence, let’s write for . Let’s suppose that is another -manifold with over which all the relevant structures extend. We’d like to compare and .

We can glue and (the latter with opposite orientation) along the boundary to obtain a closed -manifold . Then the ratio between and is

So: what we’d like is for to be equal to . Suppose that this closed -manifold is further the boundary of a -manifold , and that the Dirac operator on extends to . Then the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem on says that

The -form is the “anomaly polynomial” of the -dimensional fermion field , provided exists: this is by definition of the anomaly polynomial coupled with the above observation that the anomaly inflow of is related to . So vanishes iff is free of (perturbative?) anomalies.

In this case ( vanishing), we find that is an integer. Since we wanted , the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer implies that this would suffice if we knew that were even. This would in turn be the case if all the eigenvalues of had even multiplicity. I don’t really understand why this is the case, but the idea is to argue like in Kramers’ theorem (time-reversal symmetry in half-integer spin systems implies double degeneracy): there is supposed to be an antilinear operator on which squares to and commutes with .

What this implies is that if and vanishes, then . So if (the -dimensional fermion field we began with) has no perturbative anomaly, then the “global anomaly” is a cobordism invariant. In particular, if is nullbordant, then is independent of our choice of , and thus serves as a good definition of the partition function of . Another way of saying this is that if is the symmetry group with respect to which the -dimensional theory is anomalous (so in this case, , generated by time-reversal), then the partition function of the -manifold defines a homomorphism . (Here we’re using , because you need a spin structure to even define the Dirac operator.) That’s what this paper proposes. If you’re a homotopy theorist, you might say that

where is the Brown-Comenetz dualizing spectrum. This is basically the Freed-Hopkins approach to classifying SPT phases of matter.

The story told above can be written in somewhat more abstract terms as follows. There’s a general principle stating that -dimensional anomalies are controlled by invertible -dimensional topological quantum field theories. It’s fairly easy to see this from an intuitive point-of-view (we haven’t been doing anything else so far!). Suppose you have a -dimensional anomaly associated to some quantum field theory . Then if is a closed manifold, the complex number has some phase ambiguity. The idea is to think of as a vector in a one-dimensional complex vector space. (The phase ambiguity is absorbed by the fact that this vector space doesn’t have a preferred basis.) An invertible -dimensional TQFT is exactly an assignment of a one-dimensional vector space to a -dimensional closed manifold. Then is the “anomaly theory” of the -dimensional invertible TQFT. In the condensed matter literature, is called the boundary edge mode of the -dimensional bulk SPT phase.

The discussion above shows that the example of a massless Dirac fermion on an odd-dimensional manifold which is time-reversal invariant leads to a parity anomaly. The associated -dimensional invertible TQFT is the one which assigns to each -dimensional manifold which is a cobordism between -manifolds and the linear transformation given by multiplication by .

Random cool stuff: -dimensional anomalous -theories with a finite group are the same as elements of . (In the case , this is the same as saying that anomalous -theories are just projective representations of , which isn’t terribly hard to see if you just write down what it means to be an anomaly.) The anomaly cancellation in this case is exactly provided by the Dijkgraaf-Witten theory corresponding to the element of . I guess you could think of this as some finite group version of the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem? (Random thought: ambidexterity is supposed to construct some kind of higher chromatic Dijkgraaf-Witten theory; what does “anomaly cancellation” mean in that exotic context? Presumably there’s no real physical interpretation, but the math might be interesting.)
